title: Are jazz guitarists way better than rock guitarists? - Quora

response.answer_text: Everyone will answer this question with a question, “Better in what way?” Let’s adjust the question a little bit. Who would have an easier time playing the other’s music, a jazz guitarist or a rock guitarist? A lot of very popular rock songs are very easy to play on guitar. Rock and blues are the musical forms that get the most people to pick up the instrument in the first place. Songs as different as Tracy Chapman’s “Fast Car,” John Mellencamp’s “Jack & Diane,” and Ozzy Osbourne’s “Crazy Train” all use the same chords (A, D, E). Any remotely competent jazz guitarist can play these songs. I imagine jazz has similarly simple songs. Certainly “Blue Moon,” if you consider it jazz, isn’t harder than “Jack & Diane.” The music diverges after that. A rhythm jazz guitarist has to master a lot more chord forms than your average rock guitar player. Rock’s heavier distortion can make complex chords sound cacophonous, so power chords rule. Can a jazz player handle Black Sabbath’s “Iron Man?” Yes. I’d say that a successful jazz guitar player is better at guitar than a guitar player in a band like Nickelback. But when you get into the rarified air of the top musicians in the respective styles things change again. Could John McLoughlin create the “soundscapes” of acts like Radiohead or The Smashing Pumpkins? Maybe not. And at the same time, as much as I like their playing, Radiohead and Corgan can’t do McLoughlin’s job either. Can a jazz guitarist play Yngwie Malmsteen? No. Not that Al DiMeola can’t play as fast as Yngwie - he probably can. But at this level of speed and complexity, does Al really know the Phrygian mode as well as Yngwie? How about his sweep picking? But that isn’t to say Yngwie can play DiMeola either. Their skills probably converge on “Mediterranean Sundance” and I’d pay for that ticket. Consider Steve Vai. Can DiMeola play “Yankee Rose,” “Shy Boy,” “Whispering a Prayer,” or “Call it Sleep?” With practice, sure. But he’d probably never be comfortable in it. The clip below is of Vai and DiMeola playing a DiMeola song. Here you see that while Vai can easily play the notes, he’s still Steve Vai playing an Al DiMeola song, whammy bar and all. As far as I know, the two don’t perform a Vai song together but I’d love to hear them together on “The Attitude Song.”  Does Eddie Van Halen sound like he’s struggling with jazz chords and voicing in Big Bad Bill (with his father btw)?  And how fun would it be for EVH to sit in on a track like Russell Malone’s below - no distortion. Would he hit a home run? No. Like Al DiMeola playing Steve Vai, or Steve Vai playing Al DiMeola, this isn’t what he does. The vocabulary is different and EVH could not rely on familiar licks and runs. But Van Halen is a very underrated rhythm player who grew up around his father’s jazz musician friends - hearing him sit in with Malone would be a lot of fun.  At the same time, I’m not sure how many jazz guitarists could pull off “Cathedral,” “Spanish Fly,” or even “Little Guitars (intro).” After posting my original answer I stumbled on this clip of GE Smith (SNL Orchestra) talking about the time EVH sat in on the show. This is Eddie playing nearly impromptu jazz (blues). 30 Years Ago: Eddie Van Halen Jams on 'Saturday Night Live' And we haven’t talked about other shredders like Paul Gilbert, Buckethead, and Joe Satriani, players like Jeff Beck and Frank Zappa who really crossed boundaries, or a player like Alex Lifeson. So there you go: at the easiest end of the “classic songbook” of each genre, rock is easier but not necessarily by much. In the middle, jazz is harder because the chord forms are much harder. But as you move up the complexity of each genre, what you find is phenomenal musicians who develop techniques, licks, and an “ear” for their own genre and personal style. Some guys would have an easier time crossing over to the other style, but as a rule the jazz guitar player couldn’t just walk into the best rock guitar setting and dominate. A final thought: regardless of genre, Ralph Macchio is clearly the greatest guitar player who ever lived…

Well….. in my humble opinion, what makes a musician great is how they create a mood or convey a feeling with music. Our ancestors beat on drums, so music is already a part of everyone’s creative background. After all isn’t it creativity that separates us from all the other life on earth? Just thought I would include you drummers too. Jazz players use complex chord structures often to create a scene so to speak. While a rock player will use more single note melodies. Rock guitarists use many more different timbres that jazz guitarists. I believe that the genius lies in the simplicity. It’s easy to play fast, but most people can’t comprehend all of those notes. Therefore, it has doesn’t paint a picture as well as something simpler. Need proof? Beethoven’s fifth symphony. That beginning is something almost everyone has heard before, and it to me it sounds sort of dark. That is to say say, a sunny day family picnic isn’t what I think of when I hear it. So…. if you look at the top 100 selling albums of all time, most of them are rock. To me that means more people identify with simpler melodies than complex ones. Not that complex melodies are easy or can’t convey a feeling just as well. Just saying simple melodies appeal to more people than complex ones. 2 of the top 10 albums are Pink Floyd. The wall is number 3 (zep 4 is only a few albums ahead of it) and dark side of the moon is number 10. David Gilmour is all about very simple, slow melodies. Therefore, he appeals to the masses. Gilmour also plays “noise” really well. He doesn’t even need notes to convey a feeling. Just listen to ““one of these days” or “careful with that axe Eugene” Conclussion, one of the coolest things I’ve ever seen any guitar player do was when I saw someone use their fingers down the side of a classical guitar to make a galloping horse sound, including the Doppler affect. Didn’t use any notes or even touch the strings. Pure genius.

Rock and Jazz have different goals. My neighbor once asked me over a backyard fire pit, “who was better Clapton or Hendrix?” I chose not to finish a music degree as a trombone major because I didn’t like the idea of music, or any other art, as a contest. Is Rembrandt better than Van Gogh? I never describe guitar players with the athletic term “fast”. The answer to my neighbor is Clapton was better at stuff he practiced and so was Jimi. A comparison between jazz and rock guitar assumes the goals are the same. Rock music has been referred to as “3 chords and an attitude”. I would add to that the minor pentatonic scale. Literally millions of people on Youtube have adopted rock as their own because technically it is easy, repetitive and fun. Some rock players have advanced past this, but mostly still remain in familiar “inside” bluesy lick driven territory. The music is familiar, girls dance and the band gets paid. Eric Clapton mimicked earlier players and still does. Stevie Ray Vaughn was an awesome rock and blues guitarist but was nothing new IMO. While most rock guitarists are satisfied with rock, some get bored and want to expand. It is the same reason Bebop happened. Players in the swing bands got bored with repetitive swing music. Expanding means more harmonic colors, more exotic rhythms, more room for elaborate and personal melodic concepts. Jazz is a more cerebral discipline that requires more ear training, learning and practice. No one is ever finished learning jazz. To me jazz is more art form where rock is more performance. Rock players are lost trying to creatively play over changes and implying harmony with exotic scales because they have not developed the ears or vocabulary for it. At the same time I can’t imagine any of the great jazz guitarists having the swagger and showmanship to play with the Rolling Stones. I don’t think they compare.

I used to argue this endlessly with my jazz teacher in high school. I am a massive proponent of rock music and that man soured my interest in jazz from an early age. Jazz musicians can be great awesome people, but there is a certain tier of jazz musicians that consider jazz “the only music.” This attitude is myopic to say the least. As far as I’m concerned, Jazz is a bit of a dead language. It’s not commonly played and is certainly not spread as much as rock or even country. When I listen to or play jazz, I feel like I’m cave diving. Looking for the gems that I can bring back to my style and my playing. Brass tacks time, and here’s what I hate to admit, if you give a jazz guitarist a rock lead sheet, and “rock equipment” then they’ll probably be able to play that music in a much shorter amount of time than the opposite. If you give a rock guitarist a jazz lead sheet and some “jazz equipment” than most rock guitarists will struggle a bit longer and it will take a bit more for them to get the jazz stuff down. Here’s the thing, any great rock guitarist will take the time to study and learn some jazz. It’s great stuff to learn because it will help your brain grow. I like to revisit “The Real Book” from time to time, and if I spend a few hours playing through jazz sheets, I’ll come out of it feeling more confidant about playing rock music. I have to introduce my big “however” moment. The largest selling music in the United States is actually country music. Any serious jazz musician would scoff at that fact, and probably return to his snobbery, but therein lies the biggest problem of all. Musicians tend to get lost in studying and forget that music is about connecting to people. No matter how technically proficient an artist becomes, the bottom line for musicians is whether or not the audience is moved by the experience of a performance. For my money, I would rather be part of an AC/DC performance than see the worlds greatest jazz guitarist. Julian Lage, as amazing a guitarist as he is, often plays music that goes right over my head. So the question you’ve asked is truly not as black and white as it may seem on the surface level. I hope this doesn’t disparage anyone from following their heart. If you love jazz, you should play jazz, and likewise if you love rock. It never hurts to take the things you like most from many different genres and combine them, so I hope that anyone who reads this feels rejuvenated and delves into new music they haven’t played before.

Yes, most jazz guitarists are better. That’s because jazz is much harder to play. Jazz requires learning 100’s, and sometimes even 1000’s of chords, whereas in rock, you can get by with 3–5, and if you’re a good player, 20–60, or a 100 at most. Many jazz chords are also hard to finger, you have to stretch your fingers all over the place, awkwardly, to finger the difficult chords, and that’s why a lot of guitarists give up on learning to play jazz. There are some hard chords like that in rock music, but only a few, and most players who do that, or compose with those, know how to play jazz, and are borrowing a jazz chord. For example, George Harrison, and Eric Clapton, both have some difficult chords they use in their songs, but both of them have long fingers, and big hands, that can easily play those chords, and both studied jazz guitar playing, though they didn’t try to become jazz players. Jazz is also far more complex, musically. A jazz song, whether it is a pop jazz standard, by Cole Porter, or someone from that pop jazz vocal era, can have 5–25 chords for every line of lyric sung, while most rock songs will only have 1–3. Progressive Rock songs tend to have a lot of chords, and are an exception, but most rock doesn’t have that many chords, and country, bluegrass, the blues, etc, -all the pop song formats tend to have no more than 5–10 chords, per song to play, while a jazz pop vocal standard song could have 10–30. A more complex jazz composition, by John Coltrane, Mile Davis, Dizzy Gilepsie, etc., is going to have hundreds of chords in it, usually. There are exceptions, with some simple compositions, but they are the exceptions. To play jazz on guitar, you have to know all the hundreds of chords, and be able to do all the fingerings well, without buzzing, and stumbling, and you need to know how the jazz composition works, the music theory behind it, so you can keep up with the rest of the improvising ensemble you play with. You have to know all your scales well, to play your leads. That’s a lot to know, and practice, whereas in rock, it’s far simpler, and easier, to master playing rock music. I love rock, because the melodies can be beautiful, and a good guitar player can do all sorts of cool stuff, like varying the rhythms in the strumming, varying between arpeggios and chord strumming, and also using all sorts of effects on the electric guitar, and creating exciting tones and textures, through smart manipulation of your techniques. But as a guitar player, I can tell you that the skills involved just immediately make most jazz guitarists better on their instruments.

The answer to this question is, “It depends.” There are accomplished guitarists in both genres, musicians who have studied music for years, have played every scale imaginable until their fingers bled, can compose masterpieces, perform complex pieces live flawlessly, and have 4.0 GPAs in Masters and Doctorate degrees. There are some in both genres who are brilliant musicians without ever taking lesson number one. And both genres have hacks who just happened to be in the right place at the right time with other compatible players who all have the right chemistry. I fall into the last category. While I have not attained commercial monetary success, I have been on the receiving end of many positive accolades from the local musicians I have played with, and also from some very well known San Francisco Bay Area musicians. I call myself the exception to the drummer rules: I show up to rehearsals, shows, and sessions on time and sober, and stay that way.I have quality gear and reliable transportation.I have never locked myself inside the van.And despite being very single for most of my adult life, I was never homeless, (except for only six months 12 years before taking up the drums at age 39, and immediately after a prolonged bout with cocaine, which I have not used in 30+ years.)Which brings me to an old joke: Q- What's the difference between a jazz guitarist and a rock guitarist? A- One plays 3000 chords in front of 3 fans while the other plays 3 chords in front of 3000 fans. And one for good measure: Q- What's the difference between a jazz musician and an extra large pizza? A- The pizza can feed a family of four. Rim shot!

If you are a guitarist taking guitar lessons and you are learning your favorite heavy metal guitar solos, you soon discover that some of them are easier than they look. Bending a string with the fingers or a tremolo bar isn’t hard. A lot of solos are made up of various arpeggios, often played, say, four times, then moved up a note and played again. Once you are used to playing the riffs fast and clean, you can plug them into a lot of songs whether or not they have anything much to do with the melody. Even with bands like the Grateful Dead, a lot of that pretty soloing is primarily scales, and the amazing thing is the way the solos from the various players criss-cross. A lot of rock songs with astonishing solos use only a few chords and have pretty simple melodies. Many depend on various pedals and volume to impress people. Okay, I’m talking to open-minded aspiring rockers here. Listen to how the long dead jazz guitarist Barney Kessel plays this eighty year old classic by George Gershwin, combining chords and single strings to create a beautiful solo.  Never heard of him? He was one of the top session men in The Wrecking Crew in L.A. in the sixties and seventies and played on a LOT of rock songs you love. You can buy that transcription for $2. If you sit down with it and devote yourself to learning it, and a bunch of other songs Leduc has transcribed, you will lean an immense amount about how guitars work. I’m not saying you need to play this kind of music. But if you are ABLE to play like this, don’t you think you will be able to create much more interesting solos in your own band, with the volume and distortion? Don’t you think you will become a much better guitar player? Here’s Kenny Burrell playing a Harry Warren tune from 1942. You can learn so much from playing this.  Remember that Clint Eastwood movie “Play Misty for Me”? Here is Joe Pass playing “Misty.” Another great session man and jazz guitarist. He used to write a monthly column in “Guitar Player.” He uses a lot more scales in his solos than does Barney Kessel. He had a big influence on a few of the guitar gods from the eighties.  One of the most melodic of guitar solos (well, actually, three melodies, three solos, at once—two lead guitars and a lead bass) in rock is found is the version of George Gershwin’s “Summertime” played by Big Brother and the Hilding Company, from their great album “Cheap Thrills.” (Janis Joplin sounds great, too, of course). Catch the solos at the beginning and in the middle.  Joe Pass’s jazz solo is similarly melodic:  As guitarists, we can grow in a variety of directions. I spent years essentially playing the same basic chords with a few barre chords. Then I played fingerstyle blues. I never went toward classical. I wanted to learn jazz, but never managed it until recently. But I’ve also been studying gypsy jazz, bossa nova, choro, Western swing, and a lot more. Expand your horizons. Learn wherever you can. For example, you might recall a band called The Doors. They had a song called “Spanish Caravan” that began with an exciting passage of flamenco guitar. It was the first flamenco I’d ever heard, and it amazed me. I didn’t study that, but it would have been fun. Spread your wings! Cross-pollinate!

You’d have to define ‘better’ before being able to answer that question. If by ‘better’, you mean having more technical and instrumental skills and a greater repertoire of chords, scales, and improvisation ideas and techniques and melodic invention, jazz guitarists are probably without peer. If you mean the ability to perform solo without an accompanying orchestra or band and still play all the parts (rhythm, melody, accompaniment) simultaneously, then classical, jazz and some folk /fingerpicker players would be at the top (check out Joe Pass, Martin Taylor, and Tommy Emmanuel). If you are looking for rhythmic complexity, you would look for African, Art Rock and Jazz players to wow you. If you are looking for simplicity and expression, I’d say its Blues players. If you like a lot of distortion and interesting sound processing and effects, then Pop and Rock players are your thing. But even there, you can’t compare today’s Rock musicians with Rock musicians from 30 even years ago, because modus operandi and priorities have changed. Personally, I don’t think a discussion on ‘what makes people feel something’ comes into this. You would have to reframe the question. People respond to different music emotionally because they have developed their tastes and have had experiences, but that in itself doesn’t validate a musician being better in terms of skill or even in terms of communicative ability. Taste and opinion never trump facts. Let’s use the example of language: if a majority of adult people only respond to the most basic and fundamental stories that are written at a 6th grade level, you don’t make the claim that the author must be a genius of storytelling - instead, you rightly express your concern that the population has lost something, a level of sophistication and critical thinking you expect them to have. In our society, we are able to observe an ever-decreasing capacity to have profound human interactions and experiences due to a dependency on digital technologies, and our musical experiences have not been left unscathed by this. Also, culture and subculture influences what is meaningful music to people. There’s a well-known story of a missionary wanting to show Africans Beethoven’s 9th symphony and he had them all gather around and started to play the phonogram. After a while, one by one, they got up and left. When questioned about their departure, they said that they were waiting for the music to start, but it never did. To the missionary, Beethoven was great music because it was his culture.

I sense a bit of musical snobbery in the posts I am seeing here, namely, because the music is “complex”, it is better. No, not true. I am a classically trained keyboardist. Classical music is very complicated. Many rock guitarists (the excellent ones) have been classically trained. People who say they are simply playing scales and then move up a fret or two and repeat are being dismissive. Yes, many guitarists are taught what is referred to as box patterns, and for this reason, many guitarists do sound the same. This is true for both rock AND jazz guitarists. The problem I have with jazz music is that a lot of it in my view is contrived, particularly chord structure and timings. I like well structured music. Well structured music holds up better throughout the piece. Jazz is too loose, and when you have some of those odd timings, I do not see any cohesiveness to the music. Sorry, I just don’t. Listening to these clips, were really so annoying. It is actually considerably more difficult to improvise within a 4/4 timing than say 11/8. Again, when I see people dismissing that, it strikes me as musical snobbery. And I am sure there will be those who will accuse me of the same thing. So be it. I will say something that I am sure will rankle some. You can’t be a good jazz player unless you have studied and studied well, classical music and theory. Classical gives the foundation to all. Satriani was mentioned, where it was stated he teaches jazz to his students. I like Satch a lot. He was first classically trained as was Steve Morse, Randy Rhoades, Ritchie Blackmore, Jan Akkerman, Steve Howe, Michael Schenker, Yngwie Malmsteen, Uli van Roth just to name a few. The reason why I prefer what rock guitarists do to what jazz guitarists do is one simple reason. Emotion. Jazz guitarists are simply too much of technicians. They play the notes, but there is no emoting. What’s the point of music unless you play with feeling and get your listeners to feel something? Take someone like Al DiMeola - very technical player, but lacking in feeling. His playing does nothing for me. As to the rock guitarists mentioned here…just remember, it was guys like Blackmore, Akkerman, Howe, Beck who laid the foundation for the guitarists of the 80s and 90s. As an example, Malmsteen said, that after seeing Blackmore playing Baroque runs and Bach in concert, that is what inspired his musical journey. Blackmore studied Bach. His playing is not simply pentatonic blues scales. They are classical and middle eastern scales, arpeggios. He invented the sweeping technique (like Steve Hackett invented tapping and hammer ons). Currently, Blackmore is playing wonderful acoustic guitar now, doing amazing technical things while enhancing the music. Akkerman followed the same path. Howe, basically played classical music throughout his career be it on acoustic or electric guitar. Just listen to his work in Yes. Rock music may have started out being simple (50s, early 60s), but became very complicated (prog rock anyone?). So, to say and imply only jazz is complicated, give me a break. It’s that snobbery at work. Another point, sometimes the simplest music is the best. IMO, Toccata and Fugue in D minor is Bach’s best piece of organ music. From a technical point of view, it is fairly easy to play. But, there is such grandeur in the piece, the harmonies are superb. Music does not have to be “difficult to play” to make it great. That is a misconception I see a lot of out there. I will take guitarists such as the ones I mentioned over any jazz guitarist. They are technically skilled players with solid training and foundation who also play with emotion. Of course, this is all subjective. It all comes down to what one prefers.

Short answer yes. Longer answer involves the comparison of languages. Let's say you brush up on your Spanish that you learned in High School for that trip to San Juan. You look at all your sentences and phrases and you feel confident you can get around with the locals. Well the truth is just because you can order a drink in Spanish or tell the taxi guy where you wanna go, you probably haven't worked on it long enough to be able to sit with Old man Javier at the local coffee shop and get deep about life. Same with Jazz. Eric Clapton sitting in with Wynton Marsalis is like the gringo trying to mix in up with the locals in San Juan… you really have to know the Jazz language to be able to work your way through complex chord changes. Rock, for the most part, consists of only a few forms .. I IV V, I vi ii V, etc they don't get too intricate.. and for solos the rock guitarist’s go to is the minor pentatonic. In Jazz you Melodic Minor, half dimished, super locrian, etc So yes, for the most part, not all, but most Jazz guys are way better than rock guitarists for knowledge .. or language of music On the flip side MOST straight up jazz guys when asked to rock out or funk out they just can't do it. They're stuck in Wes World and you hear them try and they have zero feel for it.. again thats a language they don't understand

Depends. Sometimes Jazz guitarists are better in rock guitarist or even metal guitarists but sometimes many rock or metal guitarists are better than most jazz guitarists. But in general term of technique , speed and skills Jazz guitarists are better than rock guitarists in most cases but not way better. For example, Django Reinhardt in his time was one of the best guitarists and still is.  How he manages to play with two fingers is unbelievable. Guitar designer Les Paul is also known for his speed and technique,  Look at how he picks his guitar, how he changes his scales, he even used sweep picking while playing it. But many reock guitarists like Johnny Ramone have been good guitarists but not technical like jazz guitarists  He was known for his fast downpicking, high distortion uses and many palm-mute and power chords. But he’s been a rhythm guitarist for most of his life. On the other hand guitarists like Ritchie Blackmore have been very technical, fast and skilled.  Ritchie Blackmore experimented with different genres. Rock, classical, blues etc. But we could say he is a rock guitarist. Pretty much guitarists like Joe Satriani are also very technical and skilled.  How he used whammy pedal, I don’t think most jazz guitarists could do it. Conclusion: So, usually jazz guitarists are more technical, skilled, faster, I mean better than rock guitarists. But there are many skilled rock guitarists who can’t be compared with jazz guitarists.

Jazz guitarists are guitarists who play jazz using an approach to chords, melodies, and improvised solo lines which is called jazz guitar playing. The guitar has fulfilled the roles of accompanist (rhythm guitar) and soloist in small and large ensembles and also as an unaccompanied solo instrument. As guitarists, we explore new and different styles of music in an effort to satisfy our curiosity, utilize our creativity, and improve our technique in the process. We’ll compare the genres of rock and classical guitar in an effort to understand some of the foundation techniques that can inform our own playing. Now that we’ve compared some fundamental differences (and a few similarities) between rock and classical guitar, some food for thought: There is no single instrumental technique that is objectively better than any other; rather, the value of a given technique can only be judged insofar as the technique achieves the aesthetic goal of the music. Thus, if a pick helps you create the sound that you’re looking for, so be it. If you require finger style or hybrid picking to find your sound, then that is what you should use. The second one is that the audience for rock music is much, much larger than for jazz. That is an equally ‘no duh’ statement as far as I am concerned. I am a huge jazz fan, but aside from summer festivals with a bunch of groups, audiences that break into the ‘thousands’ are reserved for names like Metheny or Corea or a few others. The hybrid message is what seems to have spurred discussion. I have read through page after page micro-analyzing the monstrous complexity of rock music by tossing out one or two examples, saying that ‘jazz is the same’ based on the written chords being similar to rock music, and so on. It is stunning the amount of anguish, energy, passion and angst generated by what amounts to a humorous little quip on a graphic.

I read an interview back in the 90’s of an American jazz guitarist. He was asked about what he thought of Van Halen, Satriani, Vai, and his answer struck me : “these guys sound good, it’s a pity they don’t play anything complicated” Edit : it was Jimmy Gourley. This was an interview for a French magazine, can’t remember if it was Jazz Hot or Jazz mag’ And I remember that my guitarist friends were shocked and went on “who does he think he is?”, “that old fart couldn’t bend a note if he wanted to” and so on. But he was right : he was not talking about difficulty, but about complexity. Rock music is in essence relatively simple, harmonically and rhythmically ; it is the energy that counts and make it alive. The guys I mentioned above added their fair share of virtuosity, but they didn’t make their music more complex - and they were certainly right, because they have an audience. If they started jamming on Donna Lee or Along came Betty, they’ll quickly lose a part of their aura… The fun fact is that a lot of them can play jazz. A guy like Satriani can of course play jazz, he learnt it and teaches it! In the end, I don’t think it is that important. I remember a friend of mine who was a classical guitarist and regularly played in jazz bands. He certainly stuck out, and was not exactly appreciated. It was not due to his playing, that was evidently flawless and enough swinging : it was because of his attitude ; he always seemed to show some disdain for his fellow musicians. It was not about them, it was about the music. He wasn’t even conscious about that. Well, back to the attitude : French (crazy) guitarist Christophe Godin explains the difference between a jazz guitarist and a rock guitarist…

If your question was “Is there more to learn to become a Jazz guitarist than a Rock guitarist” I would say yes, there is. We don’t need to learn all those inversions and extensions to improvise. We can get away with a Pentatonic. Does that mean Jazz guitar players are better? No. Here are some reasons why. Just because Rock guitar players don’t need to learn minor 11th chords, it doesn’t mean we don’t know them - or could learn them in a very short time if they needed them. What really makes a difference is the individual player not the genre.Difficult and better are not the same thing. I admit, I can’t improvise when the key keeps changing, the meter is odd and the extensions added to the chords keep blurring the key, if there actually is one.How the hell do Jazz players do that? Yet, I wouldn’t consider myself inferior to someone who can do this in anyway. I didn’t learn those things because I have what I need to express myself. It would be great if I could improvise like a Jazz guitarist, but since it doesn’t fulfill my goals I’m not putting in the time. 3. The relative simplicity of the music is usually compensated for by other things such as technical complexity. Once again this depends on the individual player. Ever heard Ynwie Malmsteen or Steve Vai? Rock can get as difficult as that. Bottom line, you need more musical knowledge to play Jazz, but the variations within both Jazz and Rock (sub-genres) are huge, and the difference between each individual player are even larger.

Though I shudder at comparisons between players, in the broader (stereotyping) world of music, a jazz player of any instrument will usually be the more . . . ‘accomplished’ musician, due to the necessity of studying music theory. True, there are jazz “ear” players who don’t bother, but once someone asks you to play a 13th chord, you better know what it is. But guitar is an exception to most rules. Learning music on guitar is a little like trying to learn English using crossword puzzles. It is difficult to make sense of the linear structure of theory when you have to deal with frets running one way and strings running the other. So, at times, a jazz guitarist will appear that hasn’t a clue what the theory behind their music is, but not often. A guitarist often starts with chord patterns printed over the melody line of what is called a “lead sheet.” When you hit a chord you don’t know, you figure it out and practice it until you can play it smoothly in the song. Same thing happens in jazz, but then you will want to move up with the big boys. That’s when the manuscript score paper comes out and before you know it, you’re slogging through the circle of fifths or learning why you might want to sharp the 11th in that chord there, buster. So, maybe not in terms of technical prowess, but in the musical knowledge department, I would venture that MOST jazz guitarist are better musicians that many rock guitarists. That being said, it is rumored that the players in KISS all have music degrees and figured out how to make a monster rock band and a lot of money. The letters in their name form the anagram that said it all and is followed by most players who dance blindly down the commercial path: Keep It Simple, Stupid.

That’s all down to technical ability for each genre. There are only really a few guitarists that have successfully wandered over to different genres to become masters of all. I’m going to use one example only for you. Gary Moore - well known as a heavy rock guitarist from eh 80’s. What many people don't know is he started with blues at the age of 15 - he was so good, he attracted the attention of arguably one of the best blues players ever, Peter Green. So, Moore made all his money from heavy rock and blindingly fast solo’s for the mid to late 70’s, and influenced many of of the worlds greatest players who are out there now. He continued with a good heavy rock career all the way through the 80’s and is considered one of the best metal guitarists of all time. But, Moore literally stopped playing rock overnight and in the early 90’s started playing blues only … of course, this was a disappointment for many of his fans, but he then found fame as a blues player, and is now considered one of the finest blues players of all time if not the best. But what many people don't know is that he was a great Jazz Fusion guitarist, playing with the successful Prog Rock, Jazz Fusion band Colosseum 2 from 75–78. Can he play traditional jazz - bearing in mind he is a metal guitar god, THE blues guitar god (most blues players of note themselves cite him as the best), one of the first great jazz fusion guitarists … well take a look at this and tell me if he’s any good at pure Jazz  Of course, he’s not the only guitar player that crosses genres with ease. Eric Clapton was a blues master, but he also had fabulous skills with reggae, and other genres. I suspect, being a good guitarist with 40 years experience, and having played in several bands, some known, others not, and played session, to be a master of all genres would be difficult as there are so many. But rock and jazz are not really that far apart, so someone with the time and good theory knowledge should be able to cross those two without any problem. However, what would be awkward for the jazz master would be the use of all the little bells and whistles a rock guitarist has, like the wham bar and the different sounds you can work with pedals - the amp settings and what you can do with them, using the volume control to its best, etc. Unless you have some experience with eh genre, you cannot just cross over just like that - I can attest to that fact from personal experience.

Well, of course a jazz guitarist would say we are. But one objective reason why this is probably true is: we work way harder at being better guitar players, right from the start. Rockers can be very impatient - mostly they want to get to the bar, play and get the applause (and get laid) without any regard of how much work goes into doing just that. There are exceptions I’ll discuss below. Jazz guys start by learning to read music, studying theory and learning hundreds of standards. We spend lonely nights and weekends practicing complicated solos, practicing comping, practicing improvising over more and more complicated chord changes. I’ve been doing this for over 3 decades now, and I think I may be getting kind of decent at it. Probably not, though. Some rockers have a jazz player’s discipline and skill - guys like Jimi Hendrix and Eddie Van Halen (ETA and their antecedents, Stevie Ray Vaughn and Steve Vai) have a jazz mentality, even with a rocker attitude and style and spirit. Sure, I like their music - why wouldn’t I? And it’s never a good idea to state one is better than another as a fact when it comes to music or any art. That’s not how art works.

Depends on how you want to get your message across. Today I was working on Coltrane changes on a turnaround, but yesterday I was trying to cop Clapton’s take on Hideaway, which I double checked against Freddie’s version. Most of my time is spent studying jazz - Joe Pass, Bird, Benson - but to get too far removed from the blues is to lose contact with the roots of the music. I can tell you, unequivocally - and I’m good enough to fool a number of the people for a fair amount of the time - that Jimi Hendrix could make me look like a fool. Sure he can’t play Donna Lee, but he could nail the blues 6 ways from Sunday. You can connect with your audience - and that’s what all music is about, regardless of genre - in a number of ways: intellectually or physically. [i.e., through their brains or their balls.] - and there are an infinite number of gradations. And each individual listener has any number of gradations. What tingles me may not tingle you, physically or emotionally. So who’s better? Who’s listening? Some people are only moved by, say, Stevie Ray Vaughan - and he was a monster, hugely talented - and some people only get moved by Miles Davis on Kind of Blue. Ever checked out Mozart? That mutha could nail it. I’ve read the other answers and agree with them all, and I’ll shut up by saying that music is the language of the gods, and they don’t care about your accent.

The boundaries blur as the decades pass. I was in a jazz band with 5 bass players; one on sax and clarinet; another, a rock guitarist, on jazz guitar; a third on keyboards and various brass instruments; a fourth on drums (another rock guitarist who this time started in classical guitar); and the fifth on trombone, flugelhorn, and the actual double bass in the band. Drums and double bass were the youngest, being veritable puppies and only in their early fifties. By the time musicians get to these sorts of ages, they have had plenty of time to fiddle about with different instruments. Some people stick with their original instrument and others pick up various things. Of course some people are just straight-out talented, and bass player 3 was a very hot keyboard player who had been in a few big-name Australian rock bands, and been thrown out of most of them due to his difficult personality. He did leave the jazz band after a final gig in which he was even more red-hot than usual. The double bass player thought he was showing off and went home after the first set, but I just sat in the background and enjoyed playing along to this red-hot virtuoso at his best. So are jazz guitarists better than rock guitarists? Well, jazz and rock are two separate things, and the hot players are probably pretty good at both, provided (this is important) that they enjoy and have a good feel for jazz and rock. There is more going on in jazz, but you underestimate rock at your peril.Join a jazz band and a rock band and find out. You'll wake up one day with grey hair playing an instrument you never would have expected. but it's all good fun. Jazz is fun. Rock is fun.

Sigh… No, not really. But, yes, quite generally. If you are talking about knowledge, technique and generally ability… sometimes you cannot judge a book by its cover. To be a good Jazz player, you are required to understand a whole lot more than rock. So as a rule jazz players TEND to be more well SCHOOLED in theory and technique than rock players. To be a good Rock player, you are not required to understand a whole lot in the way of theory and such. So, in understanding things better, yes, Jazz players tend to be “better”. But there are a good number of Rock players who are quite well versed in music as a whole, understanding theory and able to read notation. You’d be surprised. And, to be honest, there are a fair number of Jazz players who cannot read notation, and learned along the way from other players the things required to be good at playing Jazz. You’d be surprised how many. So… let’s be honest. As a general rule, Jazz players can adapt to Rock easier than a Rock player can adapt to Jazz. So, there it is. (IF you cite any of this elsewhere, please include your source - me. I offer this for free to you. Please honour my authorship. Thank you.)

Metrics are the stumbling block in this comparison. Reading music and understanding theory? Jazzers have the edge but there are no doubt a few Jazz greats with little formal training; there are certainly Rock greats with lconsiderable theory and formal training. Speed — edge to rockers — perhaps. But since speed (sometimes sans accuracy) isn’t common in Jazz, who knows. Building a sound pallet without FX - Jazz; overall sound pallet considering only end results, could go to rock. And on and on we go. I do metrics for a living and so I can say that we can only compare if we have a consistent set of requirements and measurable outcomes to go by. I play mostly blues and Jazz and freely concede that I’m not a very credible rock guitarist or bassist. I’m not “fast,” more interested in interpreting a song as a group rather than a note-for-note rendition punctuated by a free form solo, etc. I don’t view any one instrument as being the lead instrument. And while I concede that vocals will always reign in popular music, I like instrumental music at least as much. In my world, there’s no missing notes because that’s an acceptable compromise in getting the speed up. Nor can I cover up anything with volume, distortion or other FX. Whole different ballgame than rock!

Have you ever heard a jazz player attempt to play rock music (especially a shreddy or bluesy solo) for the first time? It’s usually a mess because they’re used to approaching the instrument differently. With a clean sound, you have to force sound out of the instrument. With a distorted sound, you have to control the instrument as you’re trying to play it. Each one is a skill unto itself, and if you don’t work on it, you won’t be good at it. That said, jazz simply requires a more complicated musical vocabulary for basic proficiency than rock does (and I say that as a rock guitarist who was trained in jazz). Having a jazz vocabulary certainly helps my rock playing to a greater extent than having a rock vocabulary helps my jazz playing. But both do contribute to one another at the end of the day. An interesting follow up question would be “Are fusion jazz guitarists way better than both jazz and rock guitarists.”

It feels kinda strange saying it, but: yes. Typically a jazz guitarist has put much more time into studying harmony and getting to know their instrument than a rock guitarist. Pick a random jazzer and a random rocker and the jazzer almost certainly is going to be better at most things than the rocker. A good jazz guitarist can usually imitate a good rock guitarist very well while a rocker would have no hope of improvising over a set of modulating chord changes; they probably also would have a very limited set of voicings to comp with, possibly not knowing at all what to play over e.g. an F#7#11. On the other hand, I’ve known a few jazzers who sound hilarious trying to play rock music; really weak, trying to “skee-bop-a-do” over some heavy stuff, not having enough raw energy or stylistic exposure to do it right. However, I’m sure that they could if given a month or less to focus on the style while I’d be surprised if a rock guitarist could do a convincing improv on even an easy jazz tune after a month.

Just to play the other side of this, I will say “Yes”. The bar for rock guitarists is much lower than the bar for jazz guitarists. The average jazz guitarist has more knowledge and chops than the average rock guitarist. I could play guitar in a punk rock band and be very successful, with the kind of skills you can develop in about 3 months. I would argue that you should not be called a jazz guitarist unless you have knowledge of many, many chords and the ability to play over complex key changes, etc, whereas for rock, you don’t need to know much to be successful. In today’s world, rock guitar is not what it used to be. I’m sure there are still varieties of rock where virtuoso soloing is happening, and of course that can go to an extremely high level, but to my knowledge, rock guitar is devolving mainly. I’m sure there are exceptions though. But the question is not “Is Every Rock Guitarist Inferior to Every Jazz Guitarist?” All this said, I still like rock more overall than jazz, and I listen to rock more than jazz. There are not that many jazz guitarists that I really like, but Pat Metheny was my number one guitar hero for about 20 years. I also am a big fan of Al di Meola from his late 70’s era. When I listen to jazz, usually there is no guitarist. Rock without a guitarist is so strange, it’s almost funny.

My question for you is what will you get out of the answer to this question? Are you going to base your entire guitar career around the answer that you deem worthy? Jazz players play harmonically dense/coloured chord voicings, technical melodies and solo through chord changes using lots of arpeggios and modal approaches etc.. Rock guitarist chords are generally less harmonically coloured, sing their melodies and solo with the blues scale, arpeggios and they also play modes and other more coloured scales. I think jazz guitarists enjoy the challenge of getting busy on the fretboard where rock guitarists can kick back and play their part and wail a solo now and then. Also I didn't touch on riffs. Jazz riffs can float into blues land and can be a little more rhythmically complex and rock riffs are all largely very pentatonic heavy or don't stray too far from the maj/min scale. Better isn't the right word. Appropriate to the style and fitting in with the band is a more interesting way to look at it. Learn both and see what resonates with your more :)

Of course they are & far superior, not to mention smarter. As a guitarist I thought I was awesome & could copy any rock, metal or blues guy, then I studied under a Jazz guitarist & found I wasn’t S#*!. Playing fast, tuning down, & turning up the volume on your amp & the gain levels on your distortion has nothing to do with music. The Jazz guy plays dry & clean in multiple keys & run around the the “Circle of 5th’s”. Rock bands play in 1 key, most have no clue what the circle of 5th’s are let alone utilize it & have a bass, rhythm & lead guitarist as their band & most songs have no real melody. A Jazz guitarist plays all part by them self with complex chords…Chord/Melodies. The rock guy is elementary school & the Jazz guy has a PHD! Let me give you 2 guitarist for starters (who have both passed…RIP!) & if you cannot stand listening to either of them you do not understand music & their brilliance…Allan Holdsworth & Wes Montgomery. WOW!!!

I won't say better. I would rather say better equipped. Most jazz players have a fairly sound command of music theory, most read because so much jazz is in print and so much of it is played on instruments other than the guitar and isn't in TAB. As a jazz player I have been able to accept many gigs in other genres simply because I have my theory together and learning the nuts and bolts of the new style was that much easier. It is true that some elements of jazz guitar require a technique that is way beyond that which is encountered by most rock guitarists. Take chord solos. The book of Joe Pass’ Chord Solos for example is a collection of his transcribed chord melodies. Playing these requires a phenomenal technique. Creating them requires a true virtuoso.

A super advanced jazz player would technically be better yes but they may not be able to be rock guitar well. Ideally, you want to have knowledge of basic jazz theory and some chops with chords and soloing because it would really enhance your rock playing. Allman Brothers loved Miles Davis and his Kind of Blue album where there is a ton of soloing. That's why they were so good at soloing in their rock stuff!! Now if you are including metal in the rock genre, then that would rival the jazz theory and advanced music concepts. But ya, rock guitar is more simple than jazz guitar so a pure rock guitarist wouldn't get as advanced as a jazzer. Note that I'm not referring to “better” in terms of style. That's completely preferential and subjective and has nothing to do with “better”.

In some things, I bet they (on average) are since usually they do use and practice different skills and aim for different results. In some other things, they are not (on average) for the same reasons. “Better” is a matter of opinion when it comes to music. I mean sure there are different technical aspects you can evaluate (like how many notes per minute they can play or how many different techniques they can incorporate) but for the listener, those might be a bit trivial. Usually listeners only care if it sounds good (and sometimes: does it look cool). I do not think there is a genre that would dominate all the possible ways of measuring “betterness”. But both jazz and rock guitarists do play in a genre that seems to appreciate virtuosity. So in both genre’s you’ll find players so good that they’ll pretty much excel at anything.

Short answer is no. While agreeing with others that a jazz musician will probably have a deeper knowledge of music theory and all those arcane 5 note chords— that is just one direction to go deeper. My criteria for judging a musician is: has she or he gone in a new direction, perfected and explored some new area of musical expression, and brought that to an audience in an accessible way by connecting emotionally with their music? There are so many different ways of doing that. While I actually prefer to listen to jazz guitarists, I can appreciate somebody like Jimi Hendrix too. What he is doing is incomprehensible to me (from a technique point of view, since I don’t play electric). But he’s a genius nonetheless. There is simply no way to say he is better or worse than Django Reinhardt.

1.) What do you mean by rock guitarist and jazz guitarist?    Interestingly, to reach a definite answer, the identification of what a rock guitarist and jazz guitarist would need to be determined.  Considering how both genres of jazz and rock have evolved,  it's difficult to identify a jazz guitarist and rock guitarist due to vagueness and generalization.  One would have to determine how far the "rubber-band" should be stretched for the definitions of a jazz guitarist and rock guitarist.  How about the guitarist Larry Correll who plays straight ahead jazz, and fusion? Or Jimi Hendrix, a guitarist who plays rock, but has been evaluated to have some blues and jazz elements in his playing? Or John Lennon, who is a singer/songwriter and rock guitarist? How about a jazz guitar legend such as Wes Montogmery and a beginner rock guitarist who has been playing for 6 months? How do the above answers/questions fit with the definition of a jazz guitarist and rock guitarist? 2.) The answer to your initial question depends on whom you are asking. I would also like to say that while listeners might be able to pinpoint a few areas that they like to listen to in either a jazz or rock guitarists such as "catchiness," "applied music theory,"  "innovation," or "virtuosity," a key area that determines someone's music choice to be better, worse, same, or something else also depends on a psychosocial dimension: The reinforcement of one's self identity concepts such as their public self, private self, real self, etc.  According to this study, there is a correlation between personality and music preference: http://psychcentral.com/lib/preferred-music-style-is-tied-to-personality/So the answer to your initial question also depends on who you are talking to.  Reflecting on this topic, I sometimes wonder myself whether there is such a thing as a consensus or definitive answer to music questions like this.

Are jazz guitarists way better than rock guitarists? Not sure how to make the question solely about purely objective things. This happens with almost all of the music questions. Three anecdotal observations that doesn’t necessarily answer the question but which matter, I think. I don’t have figures, but my strong guess is that more jazz guitarists are classically-trained. This doesn’t make them better in and of itself but in increases the chances that they have greater technical proficiency.My sense is that a jazz guitarist needs to know more to be generally effective. As in, knowing more chords, more positions in which to play them, etc.I do think that what you have been doing for a long time, in many cases, makes you better at that thing. I wouldn’t want Billy Gibbons replaced in ZZ Top with any jazz guitarist, for example.

If by ‘way better’ you mean better at music theory and being able to read and write music, then yes, jazz guitarists are better than rock guitarists (on average). But if by ‘way better’ you mean jazz guitarists sounding better than rock guitarists, then the answer is not so clear, as it depends on personal tastes. For example, almost everyone agrees that Jimi Hendrix is, to this day, the best electric guitar player ever recorded. And yet Jimi was musically illiterate. And he never played jazz. On the other hand, one of the best jazz guitar players ever, Django Reinhardt, was completely illiterate. So there is no black-and-white answer to your question.

Jazz guitarists are miles ahead of rock guitarists, I would not really call most rock guitarist musicians.Knowing 3 chords does not make you a musician. If you put a basic standard song in front of a rock guitarist he will look at you like you have three heads. They will ask questions like what the hell is a Bb7b5 chord . Who the hell would write a song with chords like that??? Let’s just jam on a Em chord. Then they play follow the dots on the fretboard. I’m not saying that there aren’t any good rock guitarists there are just very few who can play thru a chart with very basic chord changes.

I’m not a guitarist but my brother has been playing since he was 13 years old. Even though I don’t play I do know quite a bit about music and one thing is for sure…you can’t compare a jazz guitarist to a rock guitarist because it’s two different styles. Regardless of how many chords are being played, it’s like comparing flag football to the NFL. Just because jazz may be more involved than rock doesn’t mean that the guitarist doesn’t know any less, does it? No. However, the opposite may apply also, and the guitarist may only know how to play rock. Only way to know for sure is to ask the individual guitarist. Personally, my brother and I got a chance to meet Joe Bonamassa and he told my brother if you can learn to play classical music, everything is a piece of cake.

I love the old joke “A rock player plays 3 chords in front of 10,000 people, a jazz player plays 10,000 chords in front of 3 people”. There is no comparison. Jazz guys are much, much better musicians than just about any rock player. That doesn’t mean that what they play will appeal to everyone, just that technically and musically they are better. I think that you could give most accomplished jazz guys a rock solo to learn and they could do so pretty easily. I don’t think the opposite would be the case. Just my opinion. BTW, the absolute best guitarists in any style I have ever seen are the Spanish style players. They use all ten fingers, are unbelievably musical, and can absolutely shred at the same time.

Depends on the guitarist. It seems unquestionable that you need to know and be able to do a lot more to be a passably good jazz guitarist than you do to be a passably good rock guitarist. It’s just a higher level of all-around musical understanding. However, once we’re out of the “passably good” territory, those genres are just too different to be able to properly compare their best practitioners. In the modern era there are people able to do both reasonably well, or be comfortable in some kind of an in-between compromise, but even they typically specialize. If we were to take, e. g., Joe Pass vs. Robben Ford vs. Pat Metheny vs. Allan Holdsworth vs. Steve Morse vs. Wayne Krantz vs. Mary Halvorson, how would we be able to say which of these virtuosos is way better than others? There’s no meaningful answer. Each can do things others can’t - it all depends on what you like and what you need musically.

Jazz guitarists tend to have a broader musical vocabulary then rock guitarists, but that's not doesn't mean that they necessarily know what to play to move the audience musically. In their early days, when they were almost entirely guitar-driven, the Beatles were far more popular and appreciated than jazz guitarists because they had a far keener sense of what to play. Their sense of musicality was more developed. They had a much better sense of which chords and sequences of notes would fit together in an emotionally moving way. Jazz guitarists remind me more of mathematicians than musicians. What they play may look elegant on paper, and may be deeply appreciated by fellow jazz fans, but as far as moving the larger audience musically, they're just not as good.

Respectfully, I think a lot of the answers are overthinking this and being too generous to rock guitarists. Once you are past the complete novice level, yes jazz guitarists are way better than rock guitarists. Plain and simple, any competent jazz guitarist could play any rock tune you asked them to with relatively little preparation. A standard rock guitarist would struggle with relatively simple jazz tunes. In fact, many jazz guitarists make their living playing as session or touring musicians for pop and rock acts. All of these points about different styles, languages, and techniques are interesting, but there is an objective answer here grounded in skill level. Apologies to all rock guitarists, but this is simply true.

It varies wildly, but for the most part, yes, esp the fusion guys or studio players. Some of the more traditional jazz band guitarists are awful on speed, rakes and tremolo picking though to the point they can’t play rock. In general, rock is pretty easy to play though. It’s power chords + a pentatonic solo. Really good guitarists really don’t have a lot of trouble playing anything. The difference between jazz and rock is in jazz the guitar is accompaniment, in rock, it’s lead. And jazz uses chord scale. So you see a chord and you play the scale to the chord. Most other music works on the reverse. It’s generally going to be easier for a jazz guitarist to play rock music than vice versa outside certain genres like shred, prog rock, some technical death metal and the more technical end of djent and mathrock where speed and precision is key.

I think you have to define what “better” is. From an aesthetic perspective, it’s irrelevant, because taste varies. From the idiomatic view, jazz in general has much higher requirements technically to pull off, which many others here have mentioned. Where I disagree with what some have mentioned here is that rock has a broader sound palette, and rock an easier structure. Both have now bled over into each other that there are rock bands that apply some frightening levels of jazz chops and approaches and jazz outfits that has applied rocks most terse characteristics (e.g. Living Colour, Screaming Headless Torsos, Helmet, Decoding Society, Allan Holdsworth, Burnt Sugar, GoGo Penguin, etc)

My answer is - “they think they are”.The best guitarist and most rare of breed? The guys who cando both equally well. Been playing since the 70s and have had the great privilege to play with some fantastic players (well beyond me!)Have seen many “rockers” try to lumber through faking beebop or jazz standards. Lacking the chord vocabulary or the harmonic witsthey sound pretty lame. But MORE painful has been the jazzer who thinksif he just plugs into a distortion pedal he is “rockin’ man”. Few jazzers Ihave met have any grasp of the tonal or phrasing vocabulary that makesgreat rock playing and just sound silly. The best of the best I have worked with all started as blues/rock guys who later took on the challenge of jazz.The “jazz snobs” who never did rock/blues and thought they could, on demandwhip it out because it was “a lower life form” invariably sucked at it.Alan Holdsworth, Steve Vai, Steve Morse, guys like that transcend your labels.And then there’s Buckethead!

Music is subjective and what moves one listener may not appeal to another so this question of “better” suggest it relates more to skill, technique, knowledge etc. Rock is generally simpler and more accessible and lots of it can be played with more limited skill. It can be easier to begin playing rock/blues based music. Jazz will generally require more knowledge to play so I suppose from that POV one might suggest jazz players are “better". But it is a generalization and there are many modern rock guitarists with just as deep knowledge and technique as the best jazz players. There are virtuosos in all genres that have incredible skills. Good players will normally be able to play a variety of styles.

One thing that nobody here has addressed is that there are a few great guitarists who are equally adept at playing jazz rock and pop music. Some examples would be Larry Carlton, Lee Rittenour, Russ Freeman, Grant Geissman. Larry and Lee both started as first call studio guitarist on pop and rock sessions but ultimately moved onto solo careers that gradually became jazz music. All these guys can go toe to toe with the best jazz or rock guitarist. The true great guitarist has mastered every style of those who came before them and developed their own style. Finally I must say that Steely Dan was the first rock band to fully embrace jazz. Larry played lead on many of their songs. The chords that Dan used are very much jazz and playing their songs is extremely difficult compared to most rock songs.

I suspect that any jazz guitarist who makes his living with his or her playing will be far more accomplished than pretty much any rock guitarist who makes his or her living by playing. By “accomplished” I mean nothing special or mysterious. It’s the same apparently effortless “know how” that an accomplished dog trainer like Cesar Milan demonstrates. It’s important to remember that jazz is often rather complex and it has very limited appeal (at least here in America). About the only public place where you hear jazz played these days is in “upscale casual” restaurants (high school educated restaurant managers think it’s “classy”). Intellectuals like it (except Adorno). Some Black people pretend to enjoy it, but most don’t bother. I’ve always despised it. But a few years ago when I tried to learn how to play a few blues songs on my acoustic guitar, guess who I chose to take lessons from: a jazz guitarist.

There used to be a TV programme in the UK called the ‘Old Grey Whistle Test’  It referred to the idea that if a song had a memorable melody then an ‘Old Grey’ (elderly person) could recall it and whistle it Rock guitarists rarely, if ever, play a tune that can be recalledThey commonly have brilliant technique, and expensive kitMuch of their guitar talk is about their equipment   weird rock guitars - Google Search: Rock guitars are performers. There are many young rock guitaristsJazz guitarists are musicians, and rarely will a young person play good jazz  There is plenty of bad jazzbut good jazz players transcend their instrument, and express a personal statement that is emotionally satisfying as against being impressive and entertaining

Jazz musicians in general have a much deeper understanding of music due to the complexity of jazz. Jazz harmony is much more complex than traditional rock, pop or blues forms. Someone who has spent a lot of years of their life playing rock or blues find it difficult to keep up with a jazz band. But the reverse is also true - someone who is accustomed to playing jazz often has difficulty getting the right feeling in other styles of music, they end up being "too busy" or incapable of getting into the groove. So although a jazz musician might have an advanced conception of harmonic structure, they might not sound good playing with a reggae or rock band.

I would say yes they are better- above and beyond better. Jazz music is extremely complicated. Speaking as a drummer, jazz tends to bend towards odd time signatures, tempo swings and erratic but controlled fills. I couldn’t imagine having to play a guitar over a rather sophisticated and complex rhythm. The consistency of having to play against such compositions tells me that a musician has to have a strong aptitude to understand and play in such a song. Think of it as being an engineer and having to solve for some abstract design or solution. That’s not to take anything away from Van Halen, Clapton, Mayer, Vai, etc. If they had put in the time I’m sure they could have succeeded. But knowing what we know I would have to say a jazz guitarist plays with dexterity and skill that your typical good rock guitarist does not.

At playing Jazz? Of course. At playing Rock? Not so much. It's a different skill set. Being a good jazzer generally requires a much greater knowledge of theory and the ability to play across key changes and time signatures and much more complex harmonic structures. Being a good rocker requires a great feel for the groove,  a knowledge of blues-based music, the ability to bend notes with great accuracy and an understanding of amps and effects that jazzers generally don't need. Of course, these skills are not exclusive to each style. I would say that the average jazzer is better educated than the average rocker but being great at either takes a lot of work and commitment.

It is pretty obvious to me than when you remove the marketing, the technology and the volume, rock guitarists are dwarfed compared to the inspiration, velocity and creativity of jazz guitarists. It always pains me to see lists of “best guitarists in the world” where John Mc Laughlin is at the bottom, Larry Coryell not even mentioned, not to mention Django Rheinardt or Charlie Christian.

User-13189252085764635660 summed it up perfectly. They're two completely different styles of playing. Rock is more medium to medium-fast paced music. Jazz is slow and all about the groove.  Jazz is more based around playing complete chords in different keys and sequences. Rock is more based around power chords and guitar solos. Being a rock guitarist myself, I'm more biased towards rock guitarists. But I've seen some amazingly talented jazz players at shows: Paco de Lucia is the best I've ever seen. His ability far surpasses my own and he's legendary. He's phenomenal hands down.

I learned this lesson from one of my music instructors who actually made a handsome living as a musician. I had just learned a piece from one of my favorite bands and had practiced it all week until I had it down cold. After playing it for him he looked me right in the eye and asked "do you want to be a musician or a technician?" He explained to me that there are many great technicians in the world. They can play fast, sight play, play any passage upon hearing it once, run scales and passages up and down like they were nothing. He also told me that they were not musicians but rather musical masturbators. Bob Dylan is a great musician, Neil Young is a great musician even though they are not very good technicians.

There are some jazz guitarists that are better than some rock guitarists. There are some rock guitarists better than some jazz guitarists. What and who you determine to be “better” is completely based on the style you prefer not at all on fact. I will give you a fact. If you play a note out of key or out of time in rock, country, classical, or bluegrass you have made a mistake. If you play a note out of time or out of key in jazz it is still just jazz.

In terms of mastery of the instrument, yes. Jazz is more demanding by far. As other answers have pointed out, being good at jazz will not make you automatically good at playing rock style, but the average jazz player will have a more complete mastery of the instrument than the average rock player, and the best jazz players will be able to solo at least as well as the best rock players, but over a much more complex groove.

I don’t think jazz guitarists are better but many of them know music theory and the stereotype is that rock guitarists are musically illiterate. That being said, some people either have an innate talent or they have developed an intuition so that, even though they may not know music theory, they can still create beautiful music. As far as technique goes, each style has techniques that require dedication in order to master them. So again, I wouldn’t say one style is better than another; they’re different.

This is the same as asking what is the best guitarist of all time. To compare two things you need to define methods and metrics to it, what is hard to do with musicians and probably any kind of art in general.  You could judge them by their techniques, their musical theory knowledge and going in details in all of them and would still be vague. Judging a musician is judging his soul and how good his brain can transform theory in music, and how good they can transmit their feelings. So basically comparing them is comparing the feelings they are transmitting for you. So instead of who is better, I think the best way is asking yourself what you like the most to hear and why. Which are the rock or jazz techniques, time measures and scales that makes you appreciate it? The guitarists I like the most are the one that exploit amazing techniques, such as speed picking, sweeps, two-hand playing, tapping and strings skipping in different styles and still putting a great amount of musicality. And also the ones that can mix different styles like playing Jazzy and they are soloing in a rock song. Guthrie Govan, Paul Gilbert and Joe Satriani are some of the guitarists I appreciate the most.

A solid understanding of music theory is not required to be a functional rock guitarist. A solid understanding of music theory is almost always required to be a functional jazz guitarist. So I’m comfortable saying that if you picked a random rock guitarist and a random jazz guitarist, it is likely that the jazz cat would know more theory. That said “better” is in the ear of the listener.

There isn’t even a comparison. It’s like comparing a nuclear scientist (jazz musician) to a 9 year old learning to calculate 5 + 5 (rock guitarist). That doesn’t make jazz sound any better than rock (in fact it’s generally less enjoyable, hence infinitely less popular), but they are not even remotely in the same league.

Sadly I'm not a musician but I recently saw a video of Eric Clapton after he had played with Wynton Marsalis’ jazz ensemble. Eric admitted to being incredibly intimidated playing with them. He explained how the seeming ease with which they played off of one another and how complex it was seemed overwhelming. Now Eric Clapton is of course an alien being in his own right. But he made no bones about it. He felt out of place and a foreigner in a strange land.

Power chords v Jazz chords says it all really. Ive always believed that Jazz Players brains are wired in a fundamentally different way to other people, not just Rock musicians. I don't mean they are more intellectual or superior.. The way they think, feel and perceive everything in life is slightly different. Not in a better or worse way than any other person. I'm not aware of any scientific, psychological study of Jazz Musicians minds compared to Rock or pop musicians minds, but I think it would prove, over time, there are distinct psychological differing patterns between them.

It’s a matter of opinion. I started my civilian career at NASA JPL. One of the scientists I worked with had a hobby as a flamenco guitarist, a skill parallel to jazz guitarist. He said the highlight of his hobby was jamming with Jimmy Hendricks. Different styles of guitar are different. If you’re good with the guitar you will appreciate all of the different styles but that’s not the same as being good at all of them.

Each idiom of music has their language to master. I knew jazz guitarists who hated rock and said that they could play it because it was so easy. Trust me when I say that these individuals could not come near playing rock and roll. I hold rock guitarists Jimi Hendrix, Jimmy Page, Eric Clapton, George Harrison, and Steve Lukather in as much high regard as I hold Pat Martino, George Benson, Pat Metheny, Johnny Smith, Joe Pass, Tal Farlow and so many more.

Lot's things has been said.  If money is the criteria rock guitar players (popular) way better than not only jazz but also classical guitar players.  Depends on where you're looking. You're the best guitarist at your home. (of course if you don't have Eric Johnson at home) Music is to share, to enjoy and to live. That's not a challenge...

Better at Jazz? Absolutely. Better at Rock? Nope. The language and grammar are completely different and often alien territory to the opposing sides. I can't play Jazz because I have never developed a taste for it and therefore I am merely trying to wear a mask, to mimic without any desire to be authentic, but I don't think someone as born, bred, and reared in Jazz as I am in Rock could do what I do with authenticity. It's about much more than the notes, or the chords, and far more primal a thing.

A good jazz guitarist needs a lot of training and technique to play good jazz. But it’s very unusual for any guitarist to excel in more than one or two genre. I’ve seen a number of very good jazz players who are totally lost playing rock. A master guitar player is one who completely knows and speaks fluently in a particular genre and at the same time speaks in his own voice. Some session guys are skilled at many styles but even they will have a specialty that gets them first calls.

The expressed core of jazz is improvisation. Soloists are expected to improvise for an unspecified length of time over a constantly changing rhythmic, harmonic and melody background and the sole are supposed to interact and produce their own embellishments. Rock solos are much, much shorter and are expected to be “fit in” with the song being played, and, if the song is successful, the soloist is often expected to reproduce the successful solo. Given the difference in requirements, it should not be surprising that jazz guitarists have a much greater rhythmic, melodic and harmonic vocabulary and are therefore expected to have a much greater technical command of the instrument than rock players.

“Better” from what perspective? That's highly subjective. Are medium done steaks better than well done steaks? Is chocolate better than vanilla? Cats or dogs? French fries or potatoe skins? Sunny side up or over easy? Blonde or brunette? Rock or jazz? Get my point? ArrraAGGGHHHH

Are jazz guitarists way better than rock guitarists? This is a myth. Jazz guitarists are better at playing jazz. Rock guitarists are better at playing rock. Some guitarists can play both but play one style better. Some well-rounded players can tackle both with equal skill.

Jazz guitarists per say are better educated and skillful. There is one guitarist who came up through the rock genre but plays many different styles of music and always seems to get better with age. As Les Paul was once asked who would you like to carry on your legacy, without hesitation he said Jeff Beck.

Watch Animals as Leaders. Seems like you’re trying to compare ALL Jazz music with a small segment of mainstream rock. Saying rock music’s melody and flow is relatively simple is selling rock short. In every genre there are wildly gifted guitarists. You can’t even give an ‘in general’ answer. im trying. But there’s just too much variety.

Depends on what aspect of guitar playing/musicianship you're comparing.Jazz guitarists tend to be better with chord voicings and they usually can read music. Rock guitarists are known for their soloing and rhythm patterns. Most rock guitarists don't usually read music if they have to.

They’d like to think they are! Seriously, though, any type of guitar style can be good, if it’s played right and with feeling. I know someone who plays jazz flute, and he’s often complaining about jazz musicians being unable to improvise. He says classical musicians are usually worse. If they don’t have their sheet music, they’re often lost. So there are good things and bad things about all musicians and musical forms. I do think genre limitations factor in quite heavily.

That’s really like asking - are greyhounds way better racing animals then quarter horses - the answer to that would be no- although yes, they do the same thing but how they go about it is a completely different animal (pun intended) - both genres supremely valid in their own individualistic way.

With art there is no such thing as “better.” What you might think is better is never going to be exactly the same as the next guy, and that’s ok. Jazz guitarists might be better at some things, but also, not all jazz guitarists are the same. You might like two jazz players and not even be aware that one of them is unable to read music, for example.

No. Everyone is different. Igynve malmsteen isn't better than Eddie just because he plays faster and more. There's probably a monk in a monestary who's better than anyone. But he s never on TV. Rock on bros. Colin. Chico. Aberdeen Washington. By the way. Come as you are

Questions lie this irritate me a little I must admit. Which genre would you prefer to listen to? Which instils the greatest emotional reaction for you. Obviously the answer will give you your answer whatever anyone else says, and rightfully so. If your asking which technique requires a greater skill and knowledge, then its Jazz. Would a Jazz player do a rock players riff better than the people mentioned? I doubt it.
Why not be incredibly at both like this musical wizard? https://youtu.be/IaH2C2Qe97Y    And just for fun

A good guitarist is a good guitarist. What make them better than the other one? Better in what? Technically? Number of record sales? Number of fans? Speed?
