Not even one of the measures mention above (or any other measurement parameter if exists) can be used to decide that one guitarist is better than the other, except -perhaps- in each of some of that particular measure itself only -sometime. Music is art. Not sport. Not mathematic. I think what’s better for every person is very personal, subjective and sometimes unlogical nor can be described.

Not even. For example, have you ever listened to Eddie Van Halen, Carlos Santana, Joe Satriani, recordings of Jimi Hendrix, Eric Clapton, all rock guitarists? No need to write a book or list the jazz greats either; yo’d just be showing off! Enjoy! Ken :)

Rock guitar is much easier than that of jazz in case of learning and composition and jazz technique and skill will come handy in rock as rock can blend up easily but a rock guitarist can hardly play in jazz due to the drum patterns its har to understand what to do in those pattern and a jazz song chord have more voicing then of rock band has got in an entire album.

Its so irrelevant to even discuss such a question as different numbers or songs or any music pieces differ in so many various ways. In all genres whether they may be rock, jazz, blues, classical, swing you have relatively easy music content and also all the way up the ladder to extremely difficult music to play. However if you want to generalize the rock guitarists such as Clapton, Hendrix, Page to name only 3 are mostly recognized as the best even though probably many others match them in their own styles of playing and I mean in all genres.

How to say it… every style has a different approach to music but some styles are more intricate than others. To be honest I feel that a Gipsy style or Flamenco or Classical player is on average a lot better guitar player than a blues or rock or hard rock player BUT the thing is Rock players are better at Rock which is the most important lol.

IMHO, I don’t think it’s helpful, or useful, to box guitar players into any one genre. Rock guitarists play jazz, jazz guitarists play rock, they both may play country (Brad Paisley is an amazing player) or bluegrass, or blues (Robert Johnson, B.B. King) at some point, and what about classical guitarists like Andres Segovia or flamenco players like Paco de Lucia (who played with McLaughlin)? What about Al Di Meola (who played with them both)? Listen to “Race With the Devil On Spanish Highway”. Try and box that into one genre. Further, none of these guitarists, I believe, would try and box Hendrix or SRV into one “style” or another despite the volume; they would just appreciate the beauty of their playing . Try not to categorize or “box in” players. Personally, I just know that I love to hear those six strings regardless of whoever is playing or whatever they are playing! My 2 cents.

The minimal skills required to play rock are arguably less than the minimal skills required to play jazz. However, it’s common for an advanced rock player to have skills—theory, technique, etc.—equal to an advanced jazz guitarist. Some even cross over to jazz once in a while.

Good answers below. I’ll say no. This is a long standing controversy. Jazz has more rules (ask Joni Mitchell) and rock is harmoniously limited ( in pop). So jazz needs more theory, but rock demands strong short statements.

Though I have been listening to and buying Jazz records for nearly sixty years , I was never a great fan of Jazz guitar , but that has all changed recently thanks to YouTube . I was swayed firstly by Jimmy Bruno playing Coltrane's Giant Steps , since then have discovered such greats as Philip Catherine , and French virtuoso Bireti Lagrene and Sylvain Luc. If you know any pop guitarists in their league please let me know.
Jazz players have the edge technically, and rock players have the edge artistically. But, the “best” players, jazz or rock, develop the technique to pull off (wink, wink) their artistic ideas.
Q: What’s the difference between a rock guitarist and a jazz guitarist?A: The rock guitarist plays 3 chords for 1,000 people, the jazz guitarists plays 1,000 chords for 3 people!
No guitarists are better than the other like how different instruments aren’t better than others. They play different things so comparing them doesn’t even make sense

Don’t think that for a good guitarist there may be any difference. Remember about jazz-rock.
Jazz guitarists are probably better at playing jazz and rock guitarists are probably better at playing rock.
There are no wrong notes in Jazz so it's hard to tell if they are any good or not.
No, just because a guitarist decides to play a certain genre, doesn't mean they are incapable of playing another. Of course, the simplest answer is, it depends on the guitarist.
